title: 104_hr4095
content: The Act may be cited as the "National Information Infrastructure Protection Act of 1996". It addresses computer crime. Section 1030 of title 18, United States Code is amended to include provisions regarding accessing and obtaining information willfully. Section 1030 of title 18, United States Code is amended to include provisions regarding accessing and obtaining information willfully, including communication, delivery, or transmission to unauthorized recipients, and retention without proper delivery to authorized personnel. Section 1030 of title 18, United States Code is amended to include provisions regarding accessing information from a protected computer involving interstate or foreign communication, use by or for the Government of the United States, and the value of such use not exceeding $5,000 in any 1-year period. The amendment to Section 1030 of title 18, United States Code includes provisions for causing damage to a protected computer without authorization, accessing a protected computer recklessly, and accessing a protected computer with intent to extort money or other valuables. The amendment to Section 1030 of title 18, United States Code prohibits transmitting threats to cause damage to a protected computer in interstate or foreign commerce. The amendment to Section 1030 of title 18, United States Code includes penalties of a fine or imprisonment for up to 5 years for offenses committed for commercial advantage, in furtherance of criminal acts, or if the value of information obtained exceeds $5,000. Amendments include changes to subparagraphs in paragraph (3) of the section. In Section 1030 of title 18, United States Code, amendments are made to various subsections and paragraphs, including changes to subparagraphs in paragraph (3) and striking certain paragraphs in subsections (a) and (e). The amendments to Section 1030 of title 18, United States Code, include defining the term 'damage' as any impairment to data, a program, a system, or information causing a loss of at least $5,000 in value to individuals in a year.
